questions.text: Book test is used to assess the function of adductor pollicis, Which of the following nerves supplies the muscle?
questions.solution:
Motor supply of ulnar nerve:

Book test is used to check adductor pollicis function which is supplied by ulnar nerve.

  • The patient is asked to grasp a book between the thumb and index finger. Normally, a person will grasp the book firmly with thumb extended, taking full advantage of the adductor pollicis and the first dorsal interosseous muscles.
  • If the ulnar nerve is injured, the adductor pollicis will be paralysed and the patient will hold the book by using the flexor pollicis longus (supplied by median nerve) in place of the adductor.
  • This produces flexion at the inter-phalangeal joint of the thumb This becomes more pronounced if the examiner tries to pull the book out while the patient tries to hold it. This sign is known as 'Froment's sign' or the 'book test.


For ulnar nerve remember :-

A-adductor pollicus

B-book test - for adductor pollicis

C-card test - to check palmar interossei

E- Egawa test - to check dorsal interossei

F- Froment sign.

CLAW HAND DEFORMITY

  • Paralysis of 3rd,4th lumbricals
  • Overaction of EDC and FDP
  • Intrinsic minus deformity
  • Partial claw hand- isolated ulnar nerve injury
  • Complete claw hand- ulnar nerve+median nerve injury

Reference:Maheshwari ortho 7thedition page no 67

questions.text: A 6 year old boy had sustained fracture of the lateral condyle of humerus 3 years back. He over the years had gradually developed an elbow deformity. Which of the following can be a likely outcome?
questions.solution:
• Here, the child has suffered a nonunion of the lateral condyle of humerus, which has result in a cubitus valgus deformity.
  • Because of this deformity, the Ulnar N gets stretched slowly and over time cause it to stop functioning resulting in a Tardy (late onset) Ulnar N palsy.
  • Ulnar N is the one which innervates the palmar interossei, which are the finger adductors.
  • So Tardy Ulnar N palsy will result in inability to adduct the fingers.

A lateral condyle fracture which does not show signs of healing by 3 months is said to be in nonunion. Early nonunion fracture presents with pain and instability. These patients are treated by open reduction and internal fixation with bone grafting.

Late presentation of nonunion is either a painless mass or a cubitus valgus deformity. With increasing valgus tardy ulnar nerve palsy may develop (due to stretching of ulnar nerve with increasing valgus). Severe cases are treated by corrective osteotomy (Milch osteotomy) with or without ulnar nerve transposition.

Option a) ape thumb deformity is seen in median nerve injury

Option b) pointing index is seen in median nerve injury

Option c) kiloh nevin sign is seen in median nerve and anterior interosseus nerve injury

Reference:Campbells operative orthopedics 14thedition page no 1508

questions.text: A Patient had difficulty climbing upstairs, when he was made to bear weight on right lower limb, the pelvis of the left side dropped down. Which is the structure involved causing this problem?
questions.solution:
• The test mentioned in the question is the Trendelenburg test. In a positive test the ‘normal side sags down’.
  • Here the left side sags down, so the problem is with the right side. The common cause of positive Trendelenburg test is the weakness of the gluteus medius, is supplied by the Superior gluteal N.
  • So on this case the injured nerve is the right superior gluteal N.

Common causes of positive Trendelenburg test are:-

Defect in fulcrum:Hip dislocation, advanced cases of TB hip and septic arthritis of hip joint, developmental dysplasia of hip, Perthes disease, advanced cases of AVN hip.

Defect in liver arm: Fracture head or neck of femur, coxa vara and trochanteric fractures.

Defect in power: Abductor paralysis due to poliomyelitis or superior gluteal nerve injury, tensor fascia lata and iliotibial tract palsy and L5 radiculopathy

  • During one legged stance of gait cycle, when one stands on one leg (i.e. left leg), the right side pelvis is lifted up to clear the ground.
  • This is done by contraction of abductors on the left side (mainly gluteus medius that is running between ilium and greater trochanter on lateral aspect of hip) with an intact lever arm and fulcrum.
  • If left side abductor mechanism is defective the opposite side of pelvis will dip down by virtue of gravity (positive Trendelenburg sign)
  • In this case while walking patient lurches to same side i.e. he shifts all his weight to the left side to prevent the right pelvis from dipping down and keep the pelvis leveled (Trendelenburg gait).
  • When patient lurches on both sides (positive Trendelenburg sign on both hips), it is known as "waddling gait"

Reference:Fundamentals of orthopedics by mohindra and jain page no-97

questions.text: Name the nerve that is likely injured in the following fracture?
questions.solution:
• The X-ray shows neck of fibular fracture
  • Common peroneal nerve lies close to neck of fibula
  • So neck of fibular fracture is associated with common peroneal nerve injury
  • Common peroneal nerve injury causes foot drop

Neck of humerus fracture: axillary nerve injury

Shaft of humerus fracture: radial nerve injury (spiral groove)

Medial epicondylar fracture: ulnar nerve injury

Fracture neck of radius: posterior interosseus nerve injury- finger drop (no sensory loss)

Hook of hamate fracture- deep branch of ulnar nerve

Reference:Rockwood and greens fracture in adults 9thedition page no.1069

questions.text:
Which of the following is incorrect about lesion shown on the image?
a. 30% malignant transformation
b. Epiphyseal
c. Ground glass opacity is diagnostic
d. Can occur in Metaphysis in children
e. Most Commonly Occurs in ages 40 to 60 years
questions.solution:
• Above xray image shows soap bubble appearance which is diagnostic sign for giant cell tumor
  • The X ray depicts the diagnostic Soap bubble appearance of a Giant cell tumor which is one of the commonest tumors to be seen in distal end of radius.
  • However, the commonest sites for the GCT per say are: Distal femur Proximal tibia Distal radius.
  • It’s a benign lesion with 3% mets to lung
  • On clinical examination: egg shell cracking

Giant cell tumor :-

AGE (YR):- 20-40 Slight female predominance

SITE:-Distal femur>Proximal tibia>Distal radius

PRESENTATION:- Pain, Pathologic fracture (10%-30%), Egg shell cracking sound on tapping the lesion is heard

IMAGING: -

Eccentrically located in epiphysis

Purely radiolucent (no matrix formation) Soap bubble appearance

Usually no rim of reactive bone

Abuts subchondral bone

May exhibit cortical destruction with soft tissue extension

Metaphyseal in skeletally immature patients

HISTOLOGY:-

Multinucleated giant cells in sea of mononuclear cells

Nuclei of mononuclear stromal cells identical to nuclei of giant cells- these are the actual tumor cells and not the giant cells. These stromal cells produce RANk ligands which stimulate the osteoclast further causing destruction of the bone

TREATMENT:-

Extended curettage Resection if residual bone stock inadequate with phenol or liquid nitrogen

Consider radiation for spinal/ sacral tumors Resection of pulmonary metastases

Reference:Maheshwari ortho 7th edition page no 232

questions.text: You visit a new born near your house & identify that the child has CTEV. When will you advice the baby's parents to seek consult to put a cast?
questions.solution:
• Ideally, the treatment of a child with CTEV, should be started as early as possible.
  • In the first 2 weeks of life, the mother is advised to do gentle corrective manipulation of the foot.
  • From 2 weeks onwards the child should be under the care of an orthopaedic surgeon, who will put weekly corrective casts.
  • The technique we currently use for correcting CTEV is the Ponseti technique.

Ponsetti's philosophy:

  • This philosophy is based on better understanding of the pathoanatomy of the deformed foot.
  • Serial manipulation and casting
  • Above knee casts changed every week
  • Order of correction: cavus—> adduction—> varus—> equinus
  • According to Ponsetti, the calcaneo-cuboid-navicular complex is internally rotated (adducted) under the plantarflexed talus,
  • Hence, the deformity can be corrected by bringing the complex back under the talus by gradually stretching the tight structures.
  • This is done by putting thumb pressure over the talus head (and not over calcaneo-cuboid joint as in Kite's method).
  • By doing this, the calcaneocuboid-navicular complex is externally rotated under the talar head.

Maintainable of correction:

Dennis brown splint

  • Foot maintained in abduction and dorsiflexion
  • Full time wearing till 1 year of age
  • Night time wearing till 5 years of age

CTEV shoes: day time wearing from the time starts to walk till 7 years


Features of CTEV shoes:

  • Straight inner border
  • Outer raiser
  • No heel

Reference:Essential orthopedics by Maheshwari 7thedition page no 210.

questions.text: What is not required in an emergency management of an open femur fracture?
questions.solution:
• Open reduction and internal fixation is not done on emergency basis in cases of open fractures.
  • First fracture should be stabilized with external fixator and wound should be debrided.
  • Once wound gets healed and infection is cleared thereafter open reduction and internal fixation is done.

For open fractures gustilo and Anderson classification is used for grading.

For open fractures like 3B - antibiotics coated intramedullary nails are preferred over K wires.

  • With the evolution of available nails like antibiotic impregnated nails, intramedullary nailing is now performed even in 3B fractures.
  • Although there was initial phobia for the use of intramedullary nails, their usage has become widespread not only in grade 1 and 2 but even in grade 3 injuries.

Reference:Anderson JT, Gustilo RB. Orthopedics clinics of North America, 1980; 11:56

questions.text: Feature of Klumpke's Palsy involving the lower trunks lead to?
questions.solution:
Klumpke's palsy is characterised by Complete claw hand and Horner's syndrome.

Klumpke's palsy is injury to the lower trunk C8 and partially T1.

it is type of lesion generally is caused by hyperabduction of the arm as in catching hold of a support while falling from height. the injury tears the lower trunk of the brachial plexus (mainly T1 and partly C8).

Muscles Paralyzed

  • Intrinsic muscles of the hand (lumbricals and interossei) due to T1 involvement
  • Ulnar flexors of the wrist due to C8 involvement.

Clinical Presentation


Paralysis of the intrinsic muscles of the hand causes the claw hand deformity. Horner's syndrome may be associated due to injury to sympathetic fibers to head and neck that leave the spinal cord through T1. the sensations in a narrow zone on the medial side of the forearm and hand may be diminished.

Reference:Fundamentals of orthopedics by mohindra and jain 1stedition page no 220.

questions.text: A 3 year old child comes to you with difficulty in walking. His lab report show the ALP level is 1322 IU. His x ray of wrist is given below. What is your likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Above x ray image shows widening and cupping of epiphysis which is seen in rickets patients.

Moreover elevated levels of ALP is also a feature of rickets.

RADIOLOGICAL SIGNS OF RICKETS:-

  • Delayed appearance of epiphyses.
  • Widening of the epiphyseal plates
  • Cupping of the metaphysis
  • Splaying of the metaphysis
  • Rarefaction of the diaphyseal cortex occurs late.
  • Bone deformities: Knock knees, bow legs and coxa vara are common deformities in older children.

Reference:Maheshwar ortho 7thedition page no 301.

questions.text: Which of the following marked structures affected in the terrible triad
questions.solution:
The unhappy triad(terrible triad) was described by American orthopedic surgeon D H O'Donoghue, in 1950.

He described simultaneous occurrence of tear of

  • ACL (anterior cruciate ligament)
  • MCL (medial collateral ligament) and
  • medial meniscus tear when lateral force applied to knee while the foot is fixed to the ground.

Reference:Manish kumar varshney 1stedition page no 889

questions.text: A 65 years old postmenopausal female came with persistent backache not responding to conservative treatment. History of lifting heavy weight 4 months back with progressively increasing pain that worsens on walking. The pain starts radiating down her legs after walking for around 100m distance, she however feels no pain on climbing up the stairs, most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
In most condition pain will increase on climbing up stairs. The one exception is lumbar canal stenosis, where there is relief in pain when the patients climb up stairs.

LUMBAR CANAL STENOSIS

  • Chronic condition characterised by narrowing of lumbar spinal canal causing compression of spinal cord or its emerging nerve roots
  • Most common location: L4-L5
  • Age- >65 yrs
  • Lumbar Canal stenosis is the most common reason for lumbar spine surgery in patients >65yrs
  • Males>females
  • Causes of lumbar canal stenosis:
    • Degenerative/spondylotic changes (most common)
    • Intervertebral disc prolapse
    • Post surgical
    • Vertebral fractures
    • Inflammatory: ankylosing spondylitis
    • Secondary to systemic disease- paget disease, acromegaly, fluorosis

Clinical features of lumbar canal stenosis:

  • Back pain
  • Radiation to one\both lower limbs
  • Buttock pain
  • Bowel bladder symptoms
  • Neurogenic claudication

Neurogenic claudication:

  • In lumbar canal stenosis, neurogenic claudication pain is the hall mark (i.e. pain arising in the lower back radiating down the buttock, thigh, leg to the foot especially on prolonged physical activity).
  • Pain worsens on standing or walking but is generally relieved by either bending forwards (trunk flexion) or sitting. Posture related pain in LCS is due to the fact that the available space in the central canal decreases in axial loading and extension and increases in axial distraction and flexion. this also explains that why do patients get more relief in lying on the side (allowing flexion posture) than lying flat.

For the same reason patients and walking uphill easier and pushing a shopping cart gives them relief (positive shopping cart sign) . Since they mostly remain stooped forwards to relieve pressure on their neural structures, their posture is said to be Ape like.

Differentials

An important differential is vascular claudication pain (i.e. pain due to a peripheral artery disease). Pain on standing alone is the most sensitive symptom to differentiate neurogenic claudication from vascular claudication.

Reference:Fundamentals of orthopedics by mohindra and jain page no 186.
